William Edward Beach photographs, 1931-1948

did.abstract: William E. Beach was an amateur photographer whose photographs document his hometown of Howell, Michigan and historical sites in other Michigan communities. His collection consists of photographic negatives (with some prints) and albums with prints of historic plaques and markers, statues of famous statesmen and their gravesites, early school buildings, historic houses, gristmills, sawmills, and county courthouses.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The negatives (boxes 1-4) were donated by Barbara Stoner (donor no. 6201) in October 1982. The albums (box 5) were donated by the Howell Area Archives, Howell Carnegie District Library (donor no. 1284) in February 1999.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, William Edward Beach photographs, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: William E. Beach, an insurance salesman, was an avid amateur photographer, interested in historic sites in Michigan and the eastern U.S. Beach covered the entire state of Michigan and photographed many small towns and villages.

He also documented the daily life of his hometown, Howell, Michigan, and photographed street scenes, delivery trucks, new buildings and roads under construction, gas stations, parades, storm and fire damage and prized possessions such as a car or a cow. Beach was also an active Mason and photographed many Masonic events and temples throughout the state. His photographs serve as candid documents of life in a small town in Michigan in the 1930's and 1940's.

scopecontent.p: The William E. Beach collection consists of photographic negatives (with some prints) and albums with prints of historic plaques and markers, statues of famous statesmen and their gravesites, early school buildings, historic houses, gristmills, sawmills, and county courthouses. Other subjects include tourist sites in Michigan (such as Greenfield Village or Mackinac Island) and state parks, especially those in the Upper Peninsula. His hometown of Howell, Michigan is also heavily documented.

The Beach collection is arranged into three series. In the Kodak series the negatives measure 2 3/4 by 4 1/2 inches in size and cover the years 1931 to 1948. The Leica series consists of 35-millimeter strips and were taken between the years 1936 and 1938. The third series consists of seven albums of carefully identified photographs.

An item-level listing of the contents of the Kodak and Leica series is available at the library. To aid researchers a geographic and subject index has been created and is attached to this finding aid. These indices provide the best introduction to the collection.

Beach created the photograph albums around broad topics, and each has a title. The albums include: "Michigan Historic Places," "Around Lake Erie in Ontario. Trip to Chicago Century of Progress," "Michigan Courthouses," "Michigan Ships, Monuments, Historic Places, Buildings, Creek Scenes," "Indian and Trail Markers," "Around Michigan: Historic Places, Buildings, Mills, Dams, Bridges, Masonic Buildings," and "Michigan Governors' Homes, Michigan Trees, Old Buildings of Michigan." The photos in the albums include Beach's negative number.

did.unittitle: "Around Lake Erie in Ontario. Trip to Chicago Century of Progress," 1933-1939

odd.p: includes state capitol and a few photos of Mount Vernon

did.unittitle: "Michigan Ships, Monuments, Historic Places, Buildings, Creek Scenes," 1935-1948
"Around Michigan: Historic Places, Buildings, Mills, Dams, Bridges, Masonic Buildings," 1931-1936

odd.p: (includes typewritten descriptions of Tulip Time in Holland, 1937, White Chapel, 1932, The Cascades, 1932, Old Mill Dam near Dryden, Mich., 1932, Polar Bear Monument, 1932, Ambassador Bridge, 1932, Bath, Mich. School House, 1932, Walker Tavern and Barns at Cambridge, Mich., 1932, Boulder at Tecumseh, Mich., 1932, Boulder East of Hudson, Mich., 1932, H.S. Earle Memorial, Alma, Mich., 1932, Soldiers Monument, Grand River; Boulders Monument, Hastings, Mich.; Shiawassee Square; The Stone Bell Tower, Baseline Methodist Episcopal Church near Battle Creek; Twin Towers, Irish Hills; New Masonic Home, Alma Mich., photo by Wm. R. Ladner; Old Hudson Mills School House; The Carleton School, Marshall, Mich.; The Pennington School, Macon, Mich.)

did.unittitle: "Michigan Governors' Homes, Michigan Trees, Old Buildings of Michigan," 1927-1947
Loose album pages 1931-1947 includes Lakewood Zoo near Holland, Detroit Zoo, Kellogg Bird Sanctuary

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Prior to his collection coming to the library, Beach had given Claude Stoner many of his negatives dealing with Michigan railroads. Stoner probably incorporated many of these photographs in his collection (also available at the library).

index.head: Geographic index
index.p: The Geographic index is arranged alphabetically by city, town or geographic area and cites the negative number(s) all negative related to the term. Occasionally addition descriptive information is provided. There may be two sequences of numbers; the first is for the Kodak negatives, the second for the Leica negatives.
